topic.title: Backing up the Cloud Control Plane

section.title: Default Backup and Restore
section.p: As part of the installation procedure in , automatic backup/restore jobs are uploaded from Swift into the Freezer scheduler. The backup jobs perform scheduled backups of Helion OpenStack control plane data (files/directories/db). The restore jobs can be used to restore appropriate control plane data. Additional automatic jobs can be added to backup/restore from the secure shell (SSH) server. You must use the following procedure to set up SSH backup during installation:

section.title: Setting up SSH backup
section.p: By default, during deployment, backup jobs are automatically deployed to Swift, the MySQL database, the lifecycle manager, and Swift rings. Restore jobs are also deployed for convenience. It is more secure to store those backups also outside of the Helion infrastructure. If you provide all the values required in the following file, jobs will also be deployed to backup and restore to/from an SSH server of your choice:~/helion/my_cloud/config/freezer/ssh_credentials.yml

section.title: Backing up your Helion control plane to an SSH server
section.p:
You must provide the following connection information to this server:
The SSH server IP
The SSH server port to connect to (usually 22). You may want to confirm how to open the port on Helion's firewall.
The SSH server user to connect to
The SSH private key authorized to connect to that user (see below for details of how to set up one if it is not already done)
The directory where you wish to store the backup on that server

section.title: Setting SSH information before deployment
section.p: Before running the configuration processor, edit the following file: ~/helion/my_cloud/config/freezer/ssh_credentials.ymlPlease be advised that all parameters are mandatory, and take care in providing the SSH private key.

section.title: Setting SSH information after deployment
section.p: If you already deployed your cloud and forgot to configure SSH backups, or if you wish to modify the settings for where the backups are stored, follow the following instructions:

ol.li: Edit the following file: ~/helion/my_cloud/config/freezer/ssh_credentials.ymlPlease be advised that all parameters are mandatory, and take care in providing the SSH private key.

Run the following commands: cd ~/helion git add -A git commit -m "My config" cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts _freezer_manage_jobs.ymlThis will deploy the SSH key and configure SSH backup and restore jobs for you. It may take some time before the backups occur.

section.title: Preparing the server that will store the backup
section.p:
In this example, the information is as follows:
IP: 192.168.100.42
Port: 22
User: backupuser
Target directory for backups: /mnt/backups/
Please replace these values to meet your own requirements, as appropriate.

ol.li: Connect to the server: ssh -p 22 root@192.168.100.42

Create the SSH keypair: ssh-keygen -t rsa # Just leave the default for the first question and don't set any passphrase > Generating public/private rsa key pair. > Enter file in which to save the key (/mnt/backups//.ssh/id_rsa): > Created directory '/mnt/backups//.ssh'. > Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase): > Enter same passphrase again: > Your identification has been saved in /mnt/backups//.ssh/id_rsa > Your public key has been saved in /mnt/backups//.ssh/id_rsa.pub > The key fingerprint is: > a9:08:ae:ee:3c:57:62:31:d2:52:77:a7:4e:37:d1:28 backupuser@padawan-ccp-c0-m1-mgmt > The key's randomart image is: > +---[RSA 2048]----+ > | o | > | . . E + . | > | o . . + . | > | o + o + | > | + o o S . | > | . + o o | > | o + . | > |.o . | > |++o | > +-----------------+
Add the public key to the list of the keys authorized to connect to that user on this server: cat /mnt/backups/.ssh/id_rsa.pub >> /mnt/backups/.ssh/authorized_keys

section.title: Opening ports in Helion's firewall
section.p: There is a strict policy of firewalling deployed with HPE Helion. If you use a non-standard SSH port, you may need to specifically open it by using the following process:

ol.li: When creating your model, edit the following file:~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/firewall_rules.yml

You must add a new element in the firewall-rules list, such as:
- name: BACKUP # network-groups is a list of all the network group names # that the rules apply to network-groups: - MANAGEMENT rules: - type: allow # range of remote addresses in CIDR format that this # rule applies to remote-ip-prefix: port-range-min: port-range-max: # protocol must be one of: null, tcp, udp or icmp protocol: tcp

section.title: Securing your SSH backup server
section.p:
You can do the following to harden an SSH server (these techniques are well documented on the internet):
Disable root login
Move SSH to a non-default port (that is, something other than 22)
Disable password login (only allow RSA keys)
Disable SSH v1
Authorize Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) only for that user (disable SSH shell)
Firewall SSH traffic to ensure it comes from the HPE Helion address range
Install a Fail2Ban solution
Restrict users that are allowed to SSH

Remove the key pair generated earlier on the backup server: the only thing needed is the .ssh/authorized_keys. You can remove the .ssh/id_rsa and .ssh/id_rsa.pub files. Be sure to save a backup of them somewhere.

ul.li: Take care when sizing the directory that will receive the backup.
Monitor the space left on that directory.
Keep the system up-to-date on that server.
